newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Senior officials pledge to seek peace in Cambodia.
newsitem.headline: Senior officials pledge to seek peace in Cambodia.

text.p: Cambodia's feuding coalition parties gathered hundreds of senior government and military figures in the capital on Tuesday and told them to stay out of politics.
The bid to avoid civil strife comes after mounting tension between co-premiers Prince Norodom Ranariddh of the royalist FUNCINPEC and Hun Sen of the Cambodian People's Party (CPP).
A committee of eight members from the two parties told more than 500 military, police and government officials to remain neutral.

"We hope that through this meeting we can convince national and international public opinion that leaders of the civil service and armed forces control their institutions neutrally," the CPP's co-Interior Minister Sar Kheng said in an address.
He read out a set of principles agreed on by the committee, including neutrality, peaceful resolution of conflicts, no unauthorised movement of forces and national reconciliation.
The meeting won cautious praise from diplomats and international donors, who have been concerned over continuing political instability.
"It's a start. Hopefully the two prime ministers will be influenced by this," said one Asian diplomat.
The parties' relations reached an all-time low in the wake of a deadly grenade attack on a rally led by opposition leader and Ranariddh ally, Sam Rainsy on March 30.
Matters worsened when a handful of royalist dissidents broke from Ranariddh's FUNCINPEC party in a move condemned by the prince but championed by Hun Sen, triggering coup rumours.
